Description: Twenty Sixteen is a modernized take on an ever-popular WordPress layout — the horizontal masthead with an optional right sidebar that works perfectly for blogs and websites. It has custom color options with beautiful default color schemes, a harmonious fluid grid using a mobile-first approach, and impeccable polish in every detail. Twenty Sixteen will make your WordPress look beautiful everywhere.

<?php bloginfo('name'); ?> – The title of your site, or blog name
<?php bloginfo('url'); ?> – Your site’s URL

<?php bloginfo('template_url'); ?> – Location of your site’s theme file
<?php bloginfo('description'); ?> – Displays the tagline of your blog as set in Settings > General.
<?php bloginfo('atom_url'); ?> – Link to your site’s atom URL

<?php bloginfo('pingback_url'); ?> – Pingback URL for your site
<?php bloginfo('version'); ?> – WordPress version number
<?php bloginfo('html_type'); ?> – The HTML version your site is using
<?php site_url(); ?> – The root URL for your site
<?php get_stylesheet_directory(); ?> – Location of your stylesheet folder
<?php wp_title(); ?> – Title of a specific page

")),React.createElement(MDXTag,{name:"p",components:components},"The Loop can display lots of different element for each post. Some of the most common template tags used in themes (according to the WordPress Theme Handbook) are:"),React.createElement(MDXTag,{name:"p",components:components},"next_post_link() – A link to the post published chronologically after the current post
previous_post_link() – A link to the post published chronologically before the current post
the_category() – The category or categories associated with the post or page being viewed
the_author() – The author of the post or page
the_content() – The main content for a post or page
the_excerpt() – The first 55 words of a post’s main content followed by an ellipsis (…) or read more link that goes to the full post. You may also use the “Excerpt” field of a post to customize the length of a particular excerpt.
the_ID() – The ID for the post or page
the_meta() – The custom fields associated with the post or page
the_shortlink() – A link to the page or post using the URL of the site and the ID of the post or page
the_tags() – The tag or tags associated with the post
the_title() – The title of the post or page
the_time() – The time or date for the post or page. This can be customized using standard php date function formatting."),React.createElement(MDXTag,{name:"p",components:components},"You can also use conditional tags, such as:"),React.createElement(MDXTag,{name:"p",components:components},"is_home() – Returns true if the current page is the homepage
is_admin() – Returns true if an administrator is logged in and visiting the site
is_single() – Returns true if the page is currently displaying a single post
is_page() – Returns true if the page is currently displaying a single page
is_page_template() – Can be used to determine if a page is using a specific template, for example: is_page_template('about-page.php')
is_category() – Returns true if page or post has the specified category, for example is_category('news')
is_tag() – Returns true if a page or post has the specified tag
is_author() – Returns true if a specific author is logged in and visiting the site
is_search() – Returns true if the current page is a search results page
is_404() – Returns true if the current page does not exist

sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'
  import { MDXTag } from '@mdx-js/tag'
  

export default class MDXContent extends React.Component {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props)
    this.layout = null
  }
  render() {
    const { components, ...props } = this.props

    return <MDXTag
             name="wrapper"
             
             components={components}><MDXTag name="h1" components={components} props={{"id":"wordpress-help"}}>{`WordPress Help`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`REFERNCES`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Red Bull Weekender Website`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"wordpress-theme-files"}}>{`WordPress Theme Files`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`style.css – This is your theme’s stylesheet file.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`index.php – This is the main body template for your theme. Its job is to bring together all the information in the other theme files using template tags.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`header.php – This file contains the header information that appears with the `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`<head>`}</MDXTag>{` section of your site, stuff like metadata and the link to your stylesheet.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`sidebar.php – Everything in you sidebar goes in this file, like widgets, categories, additional menus, search form, etc.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`footer.php – This file contains your footer information, such as copyright details, widgets, and social icons.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`single.php – This file displays just one post.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`page.php – When you create a page on your site, this is the template responsible.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`comments.php – This file is responsible for displaying comments.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`404.php – When visitors try to visit a page on your site that doesn’t exist, this file will general an error page.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`functions.php – This file is where you can place special functions. We always recommend creating a child theme rather than edit this file directly.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`archive.php – Display an archive with this file so visitors to your site can go way back when and read your Hello World! post.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`search.php – Help your visitors search your site with this page.
searchform.php – Display a search form for your visitors with this template file.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"define-new-theme"}}>{`Define new theme`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`This information goes at the top of your stylesheet.css file.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`/`}{`*`}{`
Theme Name: Twenty Sixteen
Theme URI: `}<MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"href":"https://wordpress.org/themes/twentysixteen/"}}>{`https://wordpress.org/themes/twentysixteen/`}</MDXTag>{`
Author: the WordPress team
Author URI: `}<MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"href":"https://wordpress.org/"}}>{`https://wordpress.org/`}</MDXTag>{`
Description: Twenty Sixteen is a modernized take on an ever-popular WordPress layout — the horizontal masthead with an optional right sidebar that works perfectly for blogs and websites. It has custom color options with beautiful default color schemes, a harmonious fluid grid using a mobile-first approach, and impeccable polish in every detail. Twenty Sixteen will make your WordPress look beautiful everywhere.
Version: 1.2
License: GNU General Public License v2 or later
License URI: `}<MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"href":"http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-2.0.html"}}>{`http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-2.0.html`}</MDXTag>{`
Tags: black, blue, gray, red, white, yellow, dark, light, one-column, two-columns, right-sidebar, fixed-layout, responsive-layout, accessibility-ready, custom-background, custom-colors, custom-header, custom-menu, editor-style, featured-images, flexible-header, microformats, post-formats, rtl-language-support, sticky-post, threaded-comments, translation-ready
Text Domain: twentysixteen`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`This theme, like WordPress, is licensed under the GPL.
Use it to make something cool, have fun, and share what you've learned with others.
`}{`*`}{`/`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"template-include-tags"}}>{`Template include tags`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Template include tags are used within one template file (for example index.php) to include (or call) the HTML and PHP found in another template file (for example header.php). While PHP has its own built-in include() statement to do this, these WordPress-specific tags make life much easier:`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="pre" components={components}><MDXTag name="code" components={components} parentName="pre" props={{"className":"language-php"}}>{`<?php get_header(); ?> – Includes the header.php file
<?php get_sidebar(); ?> – Includes the sidebar.php file
<?php get_footer(); ?> – Includes the footer.php file
<?php comments_template(); ?> – Includes your comments

//
//
// WORDPRESS HEADER/BLOG INFO TAGS
//
//

These are functions you’ll find in your theme’s header.php file, though you’ll also find them in other theme files:

<?php bloginfo('name'); ?> – The title of your site, or blog name
<?php bloginfo('url'); ?> – Your site’s URL
<?php bloginfo('stylesheet_url'); ?> – Link to your themes’s stylesheet file
<?php bloginfo('template_url'); ?> – Location of your site’s theme file
<?php bloginfo('description'); ?> – Displays the tagline of your blog as set in Settings > General.
<?php bloginfo('atom_url'); ?> – Link to your site’s atom URL
<?php bloginfo('rss2_url'); ?> – RSS feed URL for your site
<?php bloginfo('pingback_url'); ?> – Pingback URL for your site
<?php bloginfo('version'); ?> – WordPress version number
<?php bloginfo('html_type'); ?> – The HTML version your site is using
<?php site_url(); ?> – The root URL for your site
<?php get_stylesheet_directory(); ?> – Location of your stylesheet folder
<?php wp_title(); ?> – Title of a specific page
`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"other-template-tags"}}>{`Other template tags`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`These tags can be used across all of your template files, such as index.php or page.php, making it easy to display specific information anywhere you want on your site:`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="pre" components={components}><MDXTag name="code" components={components} parentName="pre" props={{"className":"language-php"}}>{`<?php the_content(); ?> – Displays the content of a post
<?php the_excerpt(); ?> – Displays the excerpt used in posts
<?php the_title(); ?> – Title of the specific post
<?php the_permalink() ?> – Link of a specific post
<?php the_category(', ') ?> – Category of a specific post
<?php the_author(); ?> – Author of a specific post
<?php the_ID(); ?> – ID of a specific post
<?php edit_post_link(); ?> – Edit link for a post
<?php next_post_link(' %link ') ?> – URL of the next page
<?php previous_post_link('%link') ?> – URL of the previous page
<?php get_links_list(); ?> – Lists all links in blogroll
<?php wp_list_pages(); ?> – Lists all pages
<?php wp_get_archives() ?> – List archive for the site
<?php wp_list_cats(); ?> – Lists all categories
<?php get_calendar(); ?> – Displays the built-in calendar
<?php wp_register(); ?> – Displays register link
<?php wp_loginout(); ?> – Displays login/logout link only to registered users
`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"other-loops"}}>{`Other loops`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`The Loop is the default mechanism in WordPress for displaying all of your posts. Exactly how many posts are retrieved is determined by the number of posts you’ve chosen to display in the “Reading” settings in your WordPress dashboard.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Within the Loop, WordPress loops through each post retrieved for the current page one at a time and formats it according to your theme’s instructions.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`You can use the Loop to do a lot of useful stuff, like:`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Display post titles and excerpts on your homepage;
Display the content and comments on a single post;
Display the content on an individual page using template tags; and
Display data from custom post types and custom fields.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="pre" components={components}><MDXTag name="code" components={components} parentName="pre" props={{"className":"language-php"}}>{`<?php
    if ( have_posts() ) :
        while ( have_posts() ) :
            the_post();
            //
            // Post Content here
            //
        endwhile; // end while
    endif; // end if
?>
`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`The Loop can display lots of different element for each post. Some of the most common template tags used in themes (according to the WordPress Theme Handbook) are:`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`next_post_link() – A link to the post published chronologically after the current post
previous_post_link() – A link to the post published chronologically before the current post
the_category() – The category or categories associated with the post or page being viewed
the_author() – The author of the post or page
the_content() – The main content for a post or page
the_excerpt() – The first 55 words of a post’s main content followed by an ellipsis (…) or read more link that goes to the full post. You may also use the “Excerpt” field of a post to customize the length of a particular excerpt.
the_ID() – The ID for the post or page
the_meta() – The custom fields associated with the post or page
the_shortlink() – A link to the page or post using the URL of the site and the ID of the post or page
the_tags() – The tag or tags associated with the post
the_title() – The title of the post or page
the_time() – The time or date for the post or page. This can be customized using standard php date function formatting.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`You can also use conditional tags, such as:`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`is_home() – Returns true if the current page is the homepage
is_admin() – Returns true if an administrator is logged in and visiting the site
is_single() – Returns true if the page is currently displaying a single post
is_page() – Returns true if the page is currently displaying a single page
is_page_template() – Can be used to determine if a page is using a specific template, for example: is_page_template('about-page.php')
is_category() – Returns true if page or post has the specified category, for example is_category('news')
is_tag() – Returns true if a page or post has the specified tag
is_author() – Returns true if a specific author is logged in and visiting the site
is_search() – Returns true if the current page is a search results page
is_404() – Returns true if the current page does not exist
has_excerpt() – Returns true if the post or page has an excerpt`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"treehouse-theme-dev"}}>{`TreeHouse Theme Dev`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Themes are within the wp-content hierarchy.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`You can manually move a folder into there.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`// template hierarchy`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`wphierarchy.com`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`left hand side shows the different types of pages`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`different types of pages towards the right that you can create`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`TH course designated for this`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`// setting up the folder`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`in the themes folder
create themes > treehouse-portfolio`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`...then`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`themes > treehouse-portfolio > index.php
themes > treehouse-portfolio > style.css
themes > treehouse-portfolio > functions.php`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Example setup: in style.css (from website)`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`/`}{`*`}{`
Theme Name: Twenty Thirteen
Theme URI: `}<MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"href":"http://wordpress.org/themes/twentythirteen"}}>{`http://wordpress.org/themes/twentythirteen`}</MDXTag>{`
Author: the WordPress team
Author URI: `}<MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"href":"http://wordpress.org/"}}>{`http://wordpress.org/`}</MDXTag>{`
Description: The 2013 theme for WordPress takes us back to the blog, featuring a full range of post formats, each displayed beautifully in their own unique way. Design details abound, starting with a vibrant color scheme and matching header images, beautiful typography and icons, and a flexible layout that looks great on any device, big or small.
Version: 1.0
License: GNU General Public License v2 or later

Tags: black, brown, orange, tan, white, yellow, light, one-column, two-columns, right-sidebar, flexible-width, custom-header, custom-menu, editor-style, featured-images, microformats, post-formats, rtl-language-support, sticky-post, translation-ready
Text Domain: twentythirteen`}</MDXTag>
